passage.title: The Voice of the Rain
passage.author: Walt Whitman
passage.content:
And who art thou? said I to the soft-falling shower,
Which, strange to tell, gave me an answer, as here translated:
I am the Poem of Earth, said the voice of the rain,
Eternal I rise impalpable out of the land and the bottomless sea,
Upward to heaven, whence, vaguely form'd, altogether changed, and yet the same,
I descend to lave the droughts, atomies, dust-layers of the globe,
And all that in them without me were seeds only, latent, unborn;
And forever, by day and night, I give back life to my own origin,
and make pure and beautify it;
(For song, issuing from its birth-place, after fulfilment, wandering,
Reck'd or unreck'd, duly with love returns.)

questions.title: Read the text and do the tasks.

passage.content:
There's nothing like the feeling of challenging yourself and winning, of taking a risk and having it succeed. That goes with so many things, and one of them is food. You have to challenge yourself with food when you travel. This is what it's all about, experiencing the way other people do things, trusting that they know what they are doing. The food stuff that seems so strange to you is actually so delicious to many others. It doesn't always work out. Sometimes the fermented horse milk in Mongolia that sounds so bad really is so bad. However if you take a chance on the following dishes, you won't be disappointed.

Haggis, Scotland
Oddly enough, when you take all of the parts of a sheep that no one else wants the heart, the liver and the lungs - grind it up. And, mix it with mutton fat, oatmeal and spices. Then pack it in a sheep's stomach and boil it for a few hours. It tastes ... really good.

Jellyfish, China
This dish can appear challenging to those of us who only associate jellyfish with the scar nature of some species of them. There's also a rubbery texture to jellyfish that some find a little challenging. However, the Chinese know what they're doing with these things. They mix jellyfish into salads, pair it with chicken, stir it through sesame oil... it's all tasty, and it's all low-fat.

Crickets, Thailand
You hear, occasionally, that insects are the protein source of the future, and to that I say: no problem. In northern Thailand, deep-fried crickets are a staple, and they're delicious. They're nutty and crunchy, perfect with salt. I still struggle, however, with the larger insects. Anything that requires more than one bite is a bridge too far for this guy.

passage.title: Cyber Security: Basic Internet Safety Tips
passage.content:
When you want to make your home secure, you lock the door. When you want to prevent your bike from being stolen, you use a bike lock. But what do you do to protect your identity online?

Modern life is fundamentally intertwined with the internet. Nearly every daily task now has the opportunity for online integration, and almost everyone owns multiple devices, including laptops, phones, and tablets. The more accounts and devices you have online, the greater the potential is for criminals to access your personal information and take advantage of you.

Online safety is important no matter your age, but there are particular concerns for vulnerable groups like children and teenagers. Here are some tips to guide you as you evaluate your online habits and make small changes to ensure your privacy and security.

Protect your Personal Information with Strong Passwords
While creating a new password, pay attention to strong password requirements. Use different user IDs for different accounts. Make the password more complicated by combining letters, numbers, and special characters. Change your passwords quite often. Don't share your passwords with other people. Prevent "auto-login", and uncheck "Keep me signed in" and "Remember my password" options on public computers.

Be Careful about WiFi
Do not trust public wifi security. Avoid connecting to unsecured public wifi networks. Surf only through secure websites. Logout immediately after you have completed your online transaction. Make sure your own wifi networks are protected with strong passwords. Change your wifi password frequently.

questions.title: Some people believe that practical, skill-based education is more important than theoretical, academic knowledge for success in today's world. Write an essay in about 200 words expressing your views on this issue.

sampleAnswer.title: Skill-Based Education vs. Academic Knowledge
sampleAnswer.content:
In the modern world, the debate over the importance of practical, skill-based education versus theoretical, academic knowledge is more relevant than ever. While both are crucial for a well-rounded individual, I believe that for ensuring employment and success, skill-based education holds a significant edge.

Academic knowledge provides a strong foundation and helps develop critical thinking. It explains the 'why' behind concepts. For instance, a physics textbook explains the principles of electricity. However, it is the skill-based training that teaches an electrician how to actually wire a house safely and efficiently. This practical application of knowledge is what employers often seek. In fields like information technology, culinary arts, or mechanics, hands-on skills are not just an advantage; they are a necessity.

Furthermore, skill-based education empowers individuals to become self-reliant. A person with plumbing or graphic design skills can start their own business, creating opportunities for themselves and others. In contrast, a purely academic degree might not directly translate into a job without further vocational training.

In conclusion, while theoretical knowledge is valuable for intellectual growth, practical, skill-based education is the key to unlocking real-world opportunities and achieving professional success. A balanced educational system that integrates both aspects is, therefore, the ideal path forward for preparing students for the challenges of today's world.

Explanation (English): The phrase "By this time next year" indicates an action that will be finished before a specific time in the future, which requires the Future Perfect tense ($will + have + past participle$).
ব্যাখ্যা (Nepali Explanation): "By this time next year" वाक्यांशले भविष्यमा निश्चित समयभन्दा पहिले सकिने कार्यलाई जनाउँछ, जसका लागि Future Perfect tense ($will + have + past participle$) को आवश्यकता पर्दछ।

subQuestions.questionEnglish: My mother said to me, "Don't waste your time playing games." (Change into indirect speech.)
subQuestions.correctAnswer: My mother forbade/advised/told me not to waste my time playing games.
subQuestions.explanation:
Explanation (English): For an imperative sentence (a command or advice) in reported speech, we use a reporting verb like 'told', 'advised', or 'forbade' followed by '(not) + to-infinitive'. 'Your' changes to 'my'.
ব্যাখ্যা (Nepali Explanation): रिपोर्टेड स्पीचमा आज्ञार्थक वाक्य (आदेश वा सल्लाह) को लागि, हामी 'told', 'advised', वा 'forbade' जस्ता रिपोर्टिङ क्रियापद प्रयोग गर्छौं र त्यसपछि '(not) + to-infinitive' प्रयोग हुन्छ। 'Your' लाई 'my' मा परिवर्तन गरिन्छ।

subQuestions.questionEnglish: The mechanic is repairing my car. (Change into passive voice.)
subQuestions.correctAnswer: My car is being repaired by the mechanic.
subQuestions.explanation:
Explanation (English): The sentence is in the Present Continuous tense (is + V-ing). The passive form is `object + is/am/are + being + V3 + by + subject`.
ব্যাখ্যা (Nepali Explanation): वाक्य Present Continuous tense (is + V-ing) मा छ। यसको passive form `object + is/am/are + being + V3 + by + subject` हो।

subQuestions.questionEnglish: He has some money in his pocket. (Change into negative.)
subQuestions.correctAnswer: He doesn't have any money in his pocket. / He has no money in his pocket.
subQuestions.explanation:
Explanation (English): The verb 'has' here is a main verb. To make it negative, we use the auxiliary 'does not' (doesn't) + 'have'. 'Some' changes to 'any' in negative sentences.
ব্যাখ্যা (Nepali Explanation): यहाँ 'has' क्रिया मुख्य क्रिया हो। यसलाई नकारात्मक बनाउन, हामी सहायक क्रिया 'does not' (doesn't) + 'have' प्रयोग गर्छौं। नकारात्मक वाक्यमा 'some' लाई 'any' मा परिवर्तन गरिन्छ।

subQuestions.questionEnglish: The children were playing in the garden. (Change into a 'Where' question.)
subQuestions.correctAnswer: Where were the children playing?
subQuestions.explanation:
Explanation (English): The underlined part "in the garden" answers the question 'Where?'. We form the question by putting the WH-word (Where) at the beginning, followed by the auxiliary verb (were), the subject (the children), and the main verb (playing).
ব্যাখ্যা (Nepali Explanation): रेखांकित भाग "in the garden" ले 'कहाँ?' प्रश्नको उत्तर दिन्छ। हामी प्रश्न बनाउन WH-शब्द (Where) लाई सुरुमा राख्छौं, त्यसपछि सहायक क्रिया (were), कर्ता (the children), र मुख्य क्रिया (playing) राख्छौं।

questions.title: Choose and copy the correct answers from the brackets to complete the given text. (Rewriting the text is not compulsory.)
questions.passage: Last year, my family and I went to (a) _____ (a/an/the/no article) Gosaikunda Lake for a trek. It is one of (b) _____ (most popular/the most popular/more popular/popular) trekking destinations in Nepal. We (c) _____ (walked/were walking/had walked/had been walking) for six hours when it started to rain heavily. If it had not rained, we (d) _____ (will reach/would reach/would have reached/will have reached) the next village that day. (e) _____ (Although/Because/Despite/In spite of) the rain, we enjoyed the journey a lot. The local people, (f) _____ (who/which/whose/whom) we met on the way, were very friendly. My father made me (g) _____ (to carry/carry/carrying/carried) my own backpack to teach me responsibility. The guide asked us, "(h) _____ (if we were/were we/are you/if you are) feeling tired?" Everyone was exhausted, (i) _____ (wasn't it/weren't they/wasn't he/didn't they)? I will never forget that trip. It is a memory (j) _____ (that/where/when/who) I will cherish forever.

gaps.explanation:
Explanation (English): Before a proper noun (Gosaikunda Lake), an article is generally not used.
ব্যাখ্যা (Nepali Explanation): कुनै खास ठाउँ वा तालको नाम (Gosaikunda Lake) अगाडि सामान्यतया article प्रयोग हुँदैन।

Explanation (English): The phrase "one of" is followed by a superlative adjective, which requires "the".
ব্যাখ্যা (Nepali Explanation): "one of" पछि superlative adjective आउँछ, जसको अगाडि "the" लाग्छ।

Explanation (English): The Past Perfect Continuous tense is used to show an action that was happening for a duration before another past action interrupted it (started to rain).
ব্যাখ্যা (Nepali Explanation): विगतमा कुनै कार्य सुरु हुनुभन्दा अगाडि केही समयदेखि चलिरहेको अर्को कार्यलाई जनाउन Past Perfect Continuous tense प्रयोग गरिन्छ।

Explanation (English): This is a Type III conditional sentence (If + past perfect, ... would have + V3), used for unreal past conditions.
ব্যাখ্যা (Nepali Explanation): यो Type III conditional वाक्य (If + past perfect, ... would have + V3) हो, जुन विगतको असम्भव अवस्थाको लागि प्रयोग हुन्छ।

Explanation (English): "Despite" is followed by a noun phrase ("the rain"). "Although" would be followed by a clause.
ব্যাখ্যা (Nepali Explanation): "Despite" पछि noun phrase ("the rain") आउँछ। "Although" पछि clause आउँछ।

Explanation (English): "Whom" is used as the object of the verb "met" to refer to people.
ব্যাখ্যা (Nepali Explanation): "Whom" लाई मानिसहरूलाई जनाउन क्रिया "met" को object को रूपमा प्रयोग गरिन्छ।

Explanation (English): The causative verb "make" is followed by a bare infinitive (verb without 'to').
ব্যাখ্যা (Nepali Explanation): "make" causative verb पछि bare infinitive (verb without 'to') प्रयोग हुन्छ।

Explanation (English): This is a reported question. The original question "Are you feeling tired?" becomes an "if" clause with statement word order (subject + verb).
ব্যাখ্যা (Nepali Explanation): यो reported question हो। "Are you feeling tired?" प्रश्न "if" clause मा बदलिन्छ र शब्द क्रम statement जस्तो (subject + verb) हुन्छ।

Explanation (English): The subject is "Everyone" which is treated as plural ("they") for the tag question when it refers to a group of people. The statement is positive, so the tag is negative.
ব্যাখ্যা (Nepali Explanation): "Everyone" ले मानिसहरूको समूहलाई जनाउँदा, ट्याग प्रश्नमा यसलाई बहुवचन ("they") मानिन्छ। वाक्य सकारात्मक भएकोले, ट्याग नकारात्मक हुन्छ।

Explanation (English): "That" is a relative pronoun used to introduce a defining clause about a thing ("a memory").
ব্যাখ্যা (Nepali Explanation): "That" एक relative pronoun हो जुन कुनै वस्तु ("a memory") को बारेमा defining clause सुरु गर्न प्रयोग गरिन्छ।
